Posts.Content: Hi Elaine, Just thought I d share my experience which might help with your decision. I met all the criteria for the oncotype test but as I live in Scotland I wasn't offered it and didn't know it even existed until it was too late to even try and find the funds to pay for it privately. So I was in the situation of having to make the chemo decision with my husband and onco based on the Nhs predict score and general chat. It was an extremely tough decision to make (eventually decided no chemo). I still live with the knowledge that a test exists that would have given me an idea of whether my tumour would have reacted well to chemo and the likelihood of it coming back, but I never had it. So yes you may fall into the difficult grey area where you still have to make the tough decision based on uncertainty but you may not. If you don't like living with uncertainty and thoughts of 'what if' then you may find it best to go for the oncotype test to increase your chance of more concrete info. I guess it all depends on how willing you are to consider chemo as a possibility. Unless you are absolutely sure you don't want chemo no matter what, having the oncotype test may help with some of the 'what if' feelings later on. Hope you get to a decision you re comfortable with, Love Lucy

Posts.Content: Hi Silvercloud, I m not sure it ll help much with your own decision but I ll share my chemo decision making process. My surgeon told me he strongly recommended me having chemo (age 41 with 2 kids, post mastectomy for stage 2 invasive, hormone positive with all lymph nodes clear, eventually found to be her 2negative), in his words "there's always benefit to chemo". Then I go to the oncology team...the nurse who 'clerked me in' gave a wry laugh when I told her the surgeon's comments. The oncologist talked me through the statistics (all a bit mind boggling) and there didn't seem to be that much of an improvement in my survival rate by adding chemo to the hormone therapy I knew I had to take. I live in Scotland and we don't get offered oncotype test and at the time i didn't know it existed. So the onco wouldn't give me a definite opinion about what to do but kind of nudged me along that for me with my results the risks outweighed the benefits. The nurse in the room very much agreed judging by her obvious non verbal communication! It was still a really hard decision to make in deciding not to have the chemo. In your case I think definitely wait for the oncotype result which may add some really useful info to the decision. And definitely talk all your worries through with the breast care nurse who can hopefully help get awnswers to your questions and give you confidence in whatever decision you make. By the way...when I saw my surgeon again after 6 months he said "I see you decided not to have chemo, I think that was a good decision!", despite his very firm stance to the opposite 6 months earlier. So personally I d say ignore your surgeons views (he/she are good at the cutting part!) and use the more specialist oncology members of the team to help you decide what's right about the chemo for you. I hope the stress of the waiting part settles a bit and you eventually come to a decision you are 'happy' to live with, Love Lucy

Posts.Content: I was fortunate enough (I hope) to avoid chemo so got through treatment hair intact. But I totally agree with the other concerns about this campaign. Even before I had cancer I was upset to see others shave their heads for charity, particularly children. I admire their fundraising ethos but a campaign like this puts pressure on loved ones and others to shave their heads or look like they don't care by keeping their own hair. And as many have said, voluntarily shaving your head in no way helps you realise what it's like to go through cancer, in particular the enormity of having to loose your hair whilst also dealing with all the other challenges of cancer. I think increasing the number of people shaving for charity just belittles the deep and complex experience of those who have no option. I have been so grateful to MacMillan for the work they do, but I think this campaign is one they shouldn't have launched.

Posts.Content: I m just getting back into swimming after my mastectomy 5 months ago. It's really helping with residual pain and cording, and it feels so good to slowly 'get going' again. It's mainly fatigue that's made me take this long to get in the pool again. I ve found I needed the higher coverage of a specialist swim suit and my old sports costume wouldn't have worked for me even with a pocket. But you'll be able to see whether that applies to you when you ve had your surgery. The specialist costumes seem to have good but subtle padding on both sides that help to even out any differences in breast shape/prosthesis shape too. If you find you do need a new costume I found it was worth spending a bit more to be confident that my prosthesis would stay in place and I had good high cleavage coverage! Looking out in the sales on sites like Amoena worked well. I haven't checked what size swim prosthesis Amoena go up to but they were very quick and helpful when I emailed them a query. Personally I found I needed the weight of a more substantial prosthesis rather than a knitted knocker to keep balanced and prevent costume riding up a bit. I hope the surgery goes well and you return to the pool before too long Love Lucy xx

Posts.Content: Hi Helsbels, I m really glad your hubby got to the gp and has got antidepressants. Try not to worry too much that he hasn't accepted the counselling yet. Posts.Content: Hi Stormy,  I too had a left mastectomy in September 2015 without reconstruction. I m still not used to that fact but it's definitely manageable. I m only a c cup so may not be best placed to give you advice, but I would try to find a post surgical bra (try asda online, debenhams online and specialist companies like Amoena). That gives support to yiur remaining breast without being too uncomfortable on the surgical side. Personally I ve found specialist vest type tops the most comfortable to wear; supportive with a built in pocket for a prosthesis. I ve only used Amoena tops which I ve got in their sales, they make nightwear too. I m sure there are plenty of other manufacturers too. Have a look; they re reassuringly normal and nice looking! Once I m wearing my prosthesis you really can't tell I ve had any surgery. I m still struggling a bit with pain and discomfort, which does impact on what I wear, but surgeon wants to see me as it's not what he d expected by now.  I don't have any great advice about how to cope emotionally. If you can let your breast care nurse know how you re feeling, and use this sight for help and support. If you re struggling post treatment there's counseling and so on available. Try and look on it as a positive treatment step if you can. Keep us posted with how you re getting on and what your treatment plan turns out to be,  Love Lucy xxx
